evidences: ATTORNEY'S BADGE: No one would believe I was a defense attorney if I didn't carry this.
FLOOR PLANS: The murder scene, the Fey & Co. Law Offices.
RECEIPT: A department store receipt with letters written in blood on the back.
WIRETAP: Found in Miss May's hotel room.
THE THINKER: The murder weapon. Looks like a statue, but it's actually a clock. Made by Larry Butz.
GLASS SHARDS: The broken remains of a glass light stand. Broken beyond all recognition.

MAYA'S CELL PHONE: Holds a conversation between the Chief and Maya. (September 5, 9:27 AM. Maya: Mia! What's up? You haven't called in a while. Mia: Well, actually there's something I want you to hold on to for me. Maya: Again? What is it this time? Mia: It's... a clock. It's made to look like that statue, 'The Thinker.' And it tells you the time! Ah... I should probably tell you, the clock isn't talking right now. Maya: Huh? It's not working? That's lame! Mia: I had to take the clockwork out, sorry. I put some papers inside it instead. Maya: Papers? Is that the evidence, then? Mia: I'll leave that one up to your imagination. See you tonight at nine.)
MIA'S AUTOPSY REPORT: Time of death: 9/5 at 9:00 PM. Cause: single blunt force trauma. Death was instantaneous.

background_transcript: Cellular: Brrring... Brrrrring...
*beep*
???: Greetings? This is Maya speaking.
Mia: Hello Maya, it's me.
???: Mia! What's happening? It's been a while since you called.
Mia: I apologize, I've been incredibly busy. How have you been?
???: Well, ISOLATED. And it's entirely YOUR responsibility. No, I'm just joking. I've been wonderful! I'm gradually adjusting to having my own residence.
Mia: That's wonderful to hear. Actually, I'm contacting you because I need a favor.
???: I understand, I understand. You need me to safeguard evidence for you?
Mia: Perceptive as always! There's considerable talk about the forthcoming trial... I simply don't feel secure keeping the evidence here.
???: I understand. So, what is it this occasion?
Mia: It's... a timepiece.
???: A timepiece?
Mia: Indeed, it's designed to resemble that sculpture, "The Thinker." And it indicates the time! I thought you might appreciate it. You've always enjoyed novelties.
???: Hey! I'm not a child anymore, Sis!
Mia: Now, now. You know I'm only teasing. Ah, I should probably inform you, the clock isn't operational at present.
???: Huh? It's malfunctioning? That's disappointing!
Mia: I had to extract the clockwork. I apologize. I inserted some documents inside it instead.
???: Documents? Is that the evidence, then? Hmm, well... there's a possibility that might be the case, yes.
Mia: Could you visit the office tonight, around 9:00, to collect it? I'll be engaged in a pretrial meeting until then.
???: Certainly, Sis, but I expect sustenance! Something delicious! Like... hamburgers! I could really enjoy a good hamburger.
Mia: Alright, alright. We'll visit our regular establishment.
???: Excellent! It's arranged! Okay, Sis, see you shortly!
Mia: Yes. I'll be waiting, Maya.
Cellular: *beep*

???: Now, Miss Fey, I'll take what belongs to me... the documents.

???: Miss Fey, you are an ineffective deceiver. Why, I notice it right over there... That must be "The Thinker" that concealed those documents.
Mia: How could you be aware...?
???: Ho hoh. You are unaware of my background? Collecting information is my profession, you see.
Mia: I... I should have exercised more caution.
???: Ho hoh. My dear Miss Fey... I am deeply sorry. But I'm afraid I must request one additional thing. Your permanent silence... Farewell, Miss Fey.

Judge: Hmm... oh dear.

Phoenix: That's when you heard it!
Edgeworth: ...

Phoenix: One way alone! And I have proof!

Phoenix: That's how you knew "The Thinker" was a clock!

evidences: ATTORNEY'S BADGE: No one would believe I was a defense attorney if I didn't carry this.
FLOOR PLANS: The murder scene, the Fey & Co. Law Offices.
RECEIPT: A department store receipt with letters written in blood on the back.
WIRETAP: Found in Miss May's hotel room.
THE THINKER: The murder weapon. Looks like a statue, but it's actually a clock. Made by Larry Butz.
GLASS SHARDS: The broken remains of a glass light stand. Broken beyond all recognition.

MAYA'S CELL PHONE: Holds a conversation between the Chief and Maya. (September 5, 9:27 AM. Maya: Mia! What's up? You haven't called in a while. Mia: Well, actually there's something I want you to hold on to for me. Maya: Again? What is it this time? Mia: It's... a clock. It's made to look like that statue, 'The Thinker.' And it tells you the time! Ah... I should probably tell you, the clock isn't talking right now. Maya: Huh? It's not working? That's lame! Mia: I had to take the clockwork out, sorry. I put some papers inside it instead. Maya: Papers? Is that the evidence, then? Mia: I'll leave that one up to your imagination. See you tonight at nine.)
MIA'S AUTOPSY REPORT: Time of death: 9/5 at 9:00 PM. Cause: single blunt force trauma. Death was instantaneous.

background_transcript: Cellular: Brrring... Brrrrring...
*beep*
???: Greetings? This is Maya speaking.
Mia: Hello Maya, it's me.
???: Mia! What's happening? It's been a while since you called.
Mia: I apologize, I've been incredibly busy. How have you been?
???: Well, ISOLATED. And it's entirely YOUR responsibility. No, I'm just joking. I've been wonderful! I'm gradually adjusting to having my own residence.
Mia: That's wonderful to hear. Actually, I'm contacting you because I need a favor.
???: I understand, I understand. You need me to safeguard evidence for you?
Mia: Perceptive as always! There's considerable talk about the forthcoming trial... I simply don't feel secure keeping the evidence here.
???: I understand. So, what is it this occasion?
Mia: It's... a timepiece.
???: A timepiece?
Mia: Indeed, it's designed to resemble that sculpture, "The Thinker." And it indicates the time! I thought you might appreciate it. You've always enjoyed novelties.
???: Hey! I'm not a child anymore, Sis!
Mia: Now, now. You know I'm only teasing. Ah, I should probably inform you, the clock isn't operational at present.
???: Huh? It's malfunctioning? That's disappointing!
Mia: I had to extract the clockwork. I apologize. I inserted some documents inside it instead.
???: Documents? Is that the evidence, then? Hmm, well... there's a possibility that might be the case, yes.
Mia: Could you visit the office tonight, around 9:00, to collect it? I'll be engaged in a pretrial meeting until then.
???: Certainly, Sis, but I expect sustenance! Something delicious! Like... hamburgers! I could really enjoy a good hamburger.
Mia: Alright, alright. We'll visit our regular establishment.
???: Excellent! It's arranged! Okay, Sis, see you shortly!
Mia: Yes. I'll be waiting, Maya.
Cellular: *beep*
[Conversation documented. September 5, 9:27 AM]
Scene: Fey & Co. Law Offices
???: Now, Miss Fey, I'll take what belongs to me... the documents.
Mia: I'm sorry, but I cannot provide what I don't possess.
???: Miss Fey, you are an ineffective deceiver. Why, I notice it right over there... That must be "The Thinker" that concealed those documents.
Mia: How could you be aware...?
???: Ho hoh. You are unaware of my background? Collecting information is my profession, you see.
Mia: I... I should have exercised more caution.
???: Ho hoh. My dear Miss Fey... I am deeply sorry. But I'm afraid I must request one additional thing. Your permanent silence... Farewell, Miss Fey.
Mia: !!!
Red... White... Blue...
Scene: Fey & Co. Law Offices

Phoenix: Oh no, I'm delayed. Hmm, that's peculiar. The chief must have departed already. She mentioned her sister was visiting so we should all dine together... ... What's that aroma...? Blood...? Mia! (Perhaps she's in her office!)
Examine
Phoenix: That scent... Blood!
Phoenix: (Someone's present!) ...! Chief? Chief...?
Phoenix: Chief!!!
Phoenix: Who are you?

Phoenix: (The unfamiliar girl fainted. I left her resting on the office couch. I returned to the chief where she lay beneath the window. Her body was still warm... I could sense it when I held her shoulder. Then, all too swiftly, it began to diminish... Until eventually she was cold.)
Phoenix: Chief...
*whee-ooo* *whee-ooo*... *whee-ooo* *whee-ooo*...
Phoenix: ! The authorities! (Sounds like they're approaching!)
Freeze! Police!
Gumshoe: Alright, I'm Detective Dick Gumshoe, understand?
Phoenix: (Gumshoe...? What a peculiar name.)
Gumshoe: We received a notification from the building opposite, understand? Got a person claiming they witnessed a homicide.
Phoenix: (It must have been that woman I observed.)
Gumshoe: Anyway, I don't want either of you moving a centimeter, understand?
Phoenix: (Wonderful. Just wonderful. Maya... Wait, she wouldn't have... no.)
Gumshoe: Whoaaaaaaaaaaaah! Excuse me!
Maya: Eek!
Gumshoe: This term "Maya" here signify anything to you?
Maya: ...! Um... that... That's my identity...
Gumshoe: WHAAAAT!? The victim inscribed this note in her own blood, understand? With her final breath, she documented the murderer's name!
Maya: K-killer...? I'm not--
Gumshoe: Case resolved! You're coming to the station, ma'am.
Maya: W-what?

Phoenix: Mia's younger sister, Maya, was detained immediately. I was taken for interrogation and wasn't released until the following morning. My eyes were exhausted... but I couldn't rest. I remained, waiting for visiting hours to commence at the detention center. I needed to speak with Maya as quickly as possible.
Scene: Detention Center - Visitor's Room
Phoenix: (Wow, they have poor Maya confined like an offender.)
Maya: Oh! It's you! The attorney... G-good morning.
Phoenix: Good morning! (She appears so fatigued...)
Maya: Um... Are you going to be my legal representative?
Phoenix: Well, that's what I wanted to discuss with you...
Maya: I-it's alright. I comprehend. ... And... I've also heard about you.
Phoenix: Heard...? Heard what regarding me?
Maya: I... was conversing with my sister on the telephone recently...
Mia: "Today was my junior colleague's first appearance in court."
Maya: Wow! Really? How did that proceed?
Mia: "It was quite the spectacle! Honestly, I was anxious the entire time. It's been a while..."
Maya: Hah! So, he failed dismally?
Mia: "...He's brilliant. One of those 'instill fear in the hearts of evil' types... The only element he's lacking is... experience."
Maya: Huh, sounds like it was entertaining! Well, I know who to approach if I ever encounter legal troubles now!
Mia: "I don't know, Maya. I think you might prefer to wait... give him three more years. That is, unless you want to be found guilty."
Maya: That's what she expressed!
Phoenix: ...
Maya: I-I'm sorry! I didn't intend to burden you...
Phoenix: No, it's fine. It's accurate, I suppose. But... simultaneously, I can't simply observe passively! When I consider the individual who did this to Mia...
Maya: ... I understand...
Maya: ... Um...!
Phoenix: Huh? Is something troubling you?
Maya: Um... I was wondering, could I request a favor?
Phoenix: ...?

Maya: This is the address of a renowned attorney. My sister provided this to me long ago. She said if I was ever in difficulty, I should contact him. And, well, I'm in difficulty. Do you think you could go ask him to represent me?
Phoenix: (Hmm...)
Maya: They informed me that if I don't secure one, the state will assign an attorney to defend me.
Phoenix: When will that happen?
Maya: They're allowing me until 4:00 this afternoon.
Phoenix: (And visiting hours are nearly concluded... I'd better hasten!) Right, I'll return!
Scene: Fey & Co. Law Offices
Phoenix: (The office is crowded with police officers. They're all diligently searching for evidence...)
???: Hey! You there! This is a crime scene, pal! No unauthorized entry! Umm... Sorry, don't I recognize you from somewhere? Wait, you're that Butz individual, aren't you!
Phoenix: No, no, Phoenix Wright. (How could anyone confuse me for Larry!?)
???: Ah, seems I misidentified the name, Mr. Wright. Sorry about that. That Butz individual, he was a murderer! And you're no murderer! Right?
Phoenix: (He WAS proven innocent...) Umm... correct. And you were...
Gumshoe: Anyway, get the name accurate. And don't address me as "Dick"...
Police: Hey, Dick! Come over here!
Gumshoe: Y-yes, sir! B-be there immediately! Umm... ahem! You're her attorney, correct, pal? If you have business here, you'd better conduct it rapidly!
Phoenix: (Whew! He believes I'm Maya's attorney...!)
Phoenix: (I suppose I've asked all the questions I need to.)
Gumshoe: You all finished, pal?
Phoenix: Um, yes, thank you. I'll be leaving now.

Gumshoe: Oh, wait. One additional matter I wanted to mention to you. I don't suppose you're planning on speaking to that witness. Regardless, you'd better not! No influencing the witness with your lawyerly methods, pal!
Phoenix: ... (Come to think of it, I had entirely forgotten about her...) The... witness?
Gumshoe: Yeah, Miss April May. I'm sorry about this... But I can't tell you anything about her!
Phoenix: (Well, you just disclosed her name. Miss May, huh?) So you've sent her home already, then?
Gumshoe: Ahah! You're attempting your lawyerly tricks on me now! She's not to leave her room until the trial!
Phoenix: (So... she's still in the hotel across the street.) I guess I should know better than to try to get a detective to divulge information.
Gumshoe: You got that right, pal!
Phoenix: (Time to visit Miss May!)
Scene: Grossberg Law Offices

Phoenix: (According to the receptionist, the senior partner is "out". She couldn't indicate when he'd return. It must be challenging to manage everything when you're a famous attorney... Not to mention operate an office like this. I guess I'll just have to return later.)
Maya: Hey! What is it? Did you meet the attorney?
Phoenix: Sorry. I haven't seen him yet.
Maya: I see...
Phoenix: (Hmm. I'd better go see if I can locate this elite attorney she's referring to.)
Scene: Gatewater Hotel - Room 303
April: Well! Hello there, handsome.
Phoenix: Umm... hi. (Smooth, Wright, very smooth.)
April: You're the lawyer, aren't you? The detective informed me... He said, "Don't say anything to that lawyer, pal!" Tee hee!
Phoenix: (Memo to self: thank Detective Gumshoe for making my task more difficult.)
April: Gee! This is all like something from a movie! It's all so thrilling I can barely contain myself! Ooh! Let me go refresh myself so I can look the part of the beautiful eyewitness!
Phoenix: (I pity the attorney that has to cross-examine this one.)
Phoenix: (There's a screwdriver protruding from this partially-open drawer. I wonder what's inside? Let's investigate...)
April: Hey! H-h-hey!!! What are you doing!? No touching! Oooh. Naughty boy! Y-you really shouldn't pry into other people's rooms, now. You wouldn't want to upset me, would you?
Phoenix: (Upset!? I thought she was going to explode momentarily! I wonder what could be inside the drawer?)
Phoenix: (Hmm... it appears Mr. Grossberg is absent. Well, perhaps I should just wait here for him to return.)
???: *Ah-HHHHEM!*
Phoenix: (If that wasn't the most exaggerated throat clearing I've ever heard!)
Grossberg: Ah hah! So, you're the one they say has been seeking me?
Phoenix: Uh... y-yes, that's me! (He looks even... more imposing than I imagined!)
Grossberg: Hmm...? That badge on your collar...? Ah, so you're an attorney, are you now?
Phoenix: Y-yes, well... yes.
Grossberg: And what do you want? I'm not especially occupied these days... Please, proceed!
Phoenix: (Not occupied...? Then why could no one contact you?)
Grossberg: Hmm? Something the matter? You came to see the one-and-only Marvin Grossberg, did you not? Well, here I am, young man! What do you want? Speak up!
Phoenix: Um... w-well, sir, actually it's concerning Maya. Maya Fey.
Grossberg: ...! Ah... yes. Maya Fey. Continue.
Phoenix: (Hmm? Why the unusual reaction?)
Grossberg: A-cha-cha. I'm really quite busy here, son. I can't accept cases on a day's notice! No, it's quite impossible.
Phoenix: W-wait a moment! How did you know the trial was tomorrow!?
Grossberg: Urk? Ahem! A-anyway... I'm afraid it's entirely impossible for me to represent her. Sorry. End of discussion.
Phoenix: (What's occurring!? He refused me before I even had an opportunity to ask him! What do I tell Maya...?)
Phoenix: ... (Looks like Detective Gumshoe has gone home. The police are still keeping themselves busy in the chief's office. No one has time to speak with me. Guess I'll head out.)
Scene: Detention Center (after examining open drawer in Gatewater Hotel - Room 303, then visiting Grossberg Law Offices)
Phoenix: Hmm... Maya's not here. She must be in questioning. They probably won't release her for a while. Maybe I'd better go speak to that attorney again.
After clearing all Talk options in Grossberg Law Offices:
Scene: Detention Center - Visitor's Room
Phoenix: Hello.
Maya: Oh! You're back! Did you find the attorney?
Phoenix: Um... well... (What do I tell her?) Well, see... (Just be honest!) I... I really don't think you should use that guy. He... didn't appear healthy. He was exceedingly thin!
Maya: ... What actually happened?
Phoenix: ...
Maya: You don't mean... He declined to help?
Phoenix: Urp.
Maya: ... I see. I've been forsaken, then.
After clearing "Your mother's enemy" Talk option in Detention Center - Visitor's Room, if all Talk options have been cleared in Grossberg Law Offices
Maya: Just a little longer now before the state-appointed attorney arrives, I guess...
Phoenix: ... (4:00 PM. Time's up. What should I do? Do I just leave her and depart...?)
Phoenix: I've made my decision! I'm going to defend you whether you desire it or not!
Maya: ! Why?
Phoenix: Why? Well...
Phoenix: I won't desert you. You can depend on me.
Maya: ... That's so kind of you... *sniff*... ...
Phoenix: Well! Let's fight this case and secure your release!
Maya: R-right! Thank you!
Phoenix: (Whew, she smiled at last. She looks like a completely different person!) One final question... You are innocent, correct?
Maya: Yes! And I trust you... So you trust me, too, okay?

Phoenix: It's a deal. (So, what next... There's something that's been bothering me... Just what was inside that strange woman's drawer? It was when I attempted to look into the drawer that she became all defensive. There must be something in there!)
Scene: Gatewater Hotel
Bellboy: Good afternoon, sir!
Phoenix: Excuse me, you are...?
Bellboy: Ah, I beg your pardon, sir! I am the bellboy of this establishment, at your service, sir.
Phoenix: Oh, right.
Bellboy: I've just come up to deliver room service, sir.
Phoenix: Um... do you know where Miss May might be?
Bellboy: Ah. I believe our guest Miss May is currently using the, er, facilities...? If you've no need of anything, I'll be taking my leave. Please, stay as long as you wish. Enjoy...
Phoenix: Yeah... Wait... no! Hey! ... (Why does it seem like every time I visit here, I end up embarrassing myself? Wait... now's my chance to investigate a bit!)
Bellboy: Ah, I almost forgot!
Phoenix: Gah! Y-you returned quickly!
Bellboy: Might I ask you to inform Miss May that there is a message for her? Please tell her that Mr. White, of Bluecorp telephoned.
Phoenix: Oh, right. Sure. (Mr. White... of Bluecorp? Where have I heard that name?)
Maya: White... That was his name. My sister told me.
Phoenix: ("White" was the name of the man who ruined Mia and Maya's mother! Could it be coincidental?)

Phoenix: There's a screwdriver inserted in that partially-open drawer. Now's my opportunity to see what's inside! ...! What do we have here! A... wiretap? Hmm! What would a woman like her be doing with an item like this?
Narration: Wiretap added to the Court Record.

Phoenix: There is definitely something suspicious about this "Miss May"! Why would she have something like this in her hotel room? There's a narrative behind all this, I know it! Alright... I'll be using this piece of evidence in tomorrow's trial, that's certain. For Maya's sake... I'll get to the bottom of this woman's story! Wait... I mean ... you understand what I mean.
April: Oh, bellboy...? Still there?
Phoenix: (Uh oh, time to flee! I look forward to confronting you tomorrow, Miss May! In court!)
September 7, 10:00 AM
Scene: District Court - Courtroom No. 1

evidences: ATTORNEY'S BADGE: No one would believe I was a defense attorney if I didn't carry this.
FLOOR PLANS: The murder scene, the Fey & Co. Law Offices.
RECEIPT: A department store receipt with letters written in blood on the back.
WIRETAP: Found in Miss May's hotel room.
THE THINKER: The murder weapon. Looks like a statue, but it's actually a clock. Made by Larry Butz.
GLASS SHARDS: The broken remains of a glass light stand. Broken beyond all recognition.

MAYA'S CELL PHONE: Holds a conversation between the Chief and Maya. (September 5, 9:27 AM. Maya: Mia! What's up? You haven't called in a while. Mia: Well, actually there's something I want you to hold on to for me. Maya: Again? What is it this time? Mia: It's... a clock. It's made to look like that statue, 'The Thinker.' And it tells you the time! Ah... I should probably tell you, the clock isn't talking right now. Maya: Huh? It's not working? That's lame! Mia: I had to take the clockwork out, sorry. I put some papers inside it instead. Maya: Papers? Is that the evidence, then? Mia: I'll leave that one up to your imagination. See you tonight at nine.)
MIA'S AUTOPSY REPORT: Time of death: 9/5 at 9:00 PM. Cause: single blunt force trauma. Death was instantaneous.

background_transcript: Gumshoe: Once we had the suspect secured, I personally inspected the crime scene.
Phoenix: Did you uncover any evidence during your investigation?
Gumshoe: Hold your horses, pal. Don't get ahead of yourself.
Gumshoe: Just listen upI'm about to share the crucial part!
Phoenix: (I've got a bad feeling about where this is going...)
Gumshoe: I discovered a note written on a piece of paper lying next to the victim's body!
Phoenix: Just because it was next to the body doesn't prove the victim wrote it!
Gumshoe: Ho hoh! Then who do you think scribbled it, wise guy?
Phoenix: Wh-who? Uh...
Phoenix: Th-the culprit! Anyone could figure that out!
Gumshoe: Hoh.
Gumshoe: You're claiming the killer wrote her OWN name? Give me a break, pal!
Phoenix: She was set up!
Edgeworth: One moment.
Edgeworth: If that's your theory, then present your evidence.
Phoenix: Uh... (Gulp!)
Edgeworth: Hah! Seems that was a bit too much for you to handle.
Edgeworth: Those who lack evidence should keep quiet, Mr. Wright.
Gumshoe: Yeah, exactly, pal!
Phoenix: (Ouch...!)
Edgeworth: Now then, Detective, share with us what was written on that memo you discovered.
Gumshoe: The word 'Maya' was written in clear, unmistakable blood!
Phoenix: Can you prove it was Mia who wrote that?
Gumshoe: Naturally, pal!
Phoenix: (Oh no... he sounds so confident. This can't be good...)
Gumshoe: Lab results confirmed that the blood belonged to the victim!
Phoenix: What sort of 'tests' are you referring to here?
Gumshoe: Huh? The kind? Um... let me think...
Gumshoe: They check the, uh, tiny bits in the blood... the... hemo... hemoglo...
Gumshoe: Hermo... goblins... hobgob... uh... Herma-goblin bobbin...
Gumshoe: I-I refuse to testify about this, pal!
Gumshoe: I'm not an expert in blood analysis!
Judge: That much is apparent. You may proceed with your testimony.
Gumshoe: Th-thank you, pal. Uh, I mean Your Honor, Sir.
Edgeworth: Detective Gumshoe.
Gumshoe: Y-yes?
Edgeworth: I anticipate your next performance review. You should too.
Gumshoe: ...O-oh...
Phoenix: (That was a complete disaster...)
Gumshoe: Right! So, where was I?
Gumshoe: Oh, rightthere was blood discovered on the victim's fingertip!
Phoenix: Detective Gumshoe!
Phoenix: There's something I need you to make absolutely clear for me.
Phoenix: You claim that the victim, Mia Fey, wrote this note.
Phoenix: That she was accusing the defendant, Maya Fey?
Phoenix: Is that really your position?
Gumshoe: Wh-what? You're not trying one of those lawyer tricks, are you?
Gumshoe: Of course she wrote it! Who else would have!?
Phoenix: You've got it completely backward, Detective.
Gumshoe: B-backward?
Phoenix: The victim is the one person who absolutely could NOT have written it!
Phoenix: This is a report from your own department, Detective.
Phoenix: "Instantaneous death caused by a blow from a blunt object."
Phoenix: She died on the spot!
Gumshoe: But...!
Phoenix: No 'but's, Detective! You can't escape the facts!
Judge: Order! Order in the court!
Judge: The defense has raised a valid point.
Judge: Someone who dies instantly would not have the opportunity to write anything.
Edgeworth: Mr. Wright.
Edgeworth: Pardon me, but when exactly did you obtain that autopsy report?
Phoenix: Wh-when...!?
Phoenix: I received it the day following the incident...
Judge: The prosecution's point being...?
Edgeworth: That autopsy report is outdated.
Phoenix: Wh-what!?
Edgeworth: A second autopsy was conducted yesterday, at my request!
Edgeworth: "Death was almost instantaneous due to a blow from a blunt object..."
Edgeworth: "However, there is a possibility that the victim survived for several minutes after the impact."
Edgeworth: I received these updated results this morning.
Phoenix: N-no way!
Edgeworth: Your Honor!
Edgeworth: It is entirely plausible that the victim had enough time to write "Maya"!
Edgeworth: That concludes my argument.
Judge: I see!
Phoenix: (Curse you, Edgeworth!)
Phoenix: (I should have expected you'd have a trick up your sleeve!)
Edgeworth: Oh my, Mr. Wright, you seem stunned!
Edgeworth: Is there something you'd like to say?
Phoenix: Mr. Edgeworth...
Phoenix: I've heard you'd do anything to secure a guilty verdict...
Phoenix: But what was your reason for requesting a second autopsy report?
Judge: Mr. Wright! The defense will refrain from attacking the prosecution's integrity!
Edgeworth: No concern, Your Honor...
Edgeworth: Say whatever you wishthis report's findings are undeniable.
Edgeworth: Your Honor, I present this updated autopsy report to the court.
Judge: U-understood. The court will accept this new evidence.
Narrator: Autopsy Report updated in the Court Record.
Edgeworth: Now then, Your Honor.
Edgeworth: The evidence strongly implies that the victim was identifying her killer.
Judge: I suppose that's the most logical conclusion, yes.
Phoenix: (This is bad!)
Edgeworth: The prosecution now calls its next witness.
Edgeworth: A poor, innocent young woman who witnessed the crime with her own eyes!
Judge: Let Miss April May step forward.
Phoenix: (Which part of her is "innocent," exactly...?)
Edgeworth: Witness, please state your name for the record.
April: April May! At your service! *wink*
Judge: Order!
Judge: The witness will refrain from unnecessary winking!
April: Aww... Yes, Your Honor.
Phoenix: (This is not looking good...)
Phoenix: (She's already charmed every man in the courtroom!)
Edgeworth: Please tell us, where were you on the night of September 5, when the incident occurred?
April: Um... well, I was, like, in my hotel room? Tee hee.
April: I checked in shortly after lunch.
Edgeworth: And this hotel is directly across from the Fey & Co. Law Offices?
April: Mmm... that's right, handsome.
Judge: Please provide your testimony about what you witnessed.
SYSTEM: -- Witness's Account --
April: It was, like, 9:00 PM. I looked out the window, you know?
April: And then, oooh! I saw a woman with long hair being attacked!
April: The one attacking her was that mousy girl sitting over there in the defendant's chair!
April: The woman tried to dodge to the side and run away!
April: But the girl chased her down and... and... struck her!
April: The woman with the long hair...
April: She just... collapsed.
April: That's it. That's all I saw. Every little bitsy witsy!
Judge: Hmm...
Judge: I see. This is quite a compelling testimony.
Judge: I don't see any reason to further trouble the witness...
Phoenix: W-wait, Your Honor!
Judge: Yes, Mr. Wright?
Phoenix: What about my cross-examination!?
Judge: I must say, the witness's account seemed quite... solid. Don't you agree?
Edgeworth: Mr. Wright... I understand you were Ms. Mia Fey's understudy, correct?
Edgeworth: You must be familiar with her methods.
Edgeworth: Her habit of nitpicking and undermining perfectly valid testimonies...
Phoenix: H-hey! That's uncalled for!
Judge: Well, Mr. Wright? Do you wish to cross-examine the witness?
Phoenix: Absolutely. I'll proceed with the cross-examination.
Phoenix: (Especially since I have a hunch Edgeworth doesn't want me to!)
Phoenix: (There has to be a flaw in her testimony somewhere!)
Judge: Very well, you may begin your cross-examination.
NONE: -- Witness's Account --
Phoenix: Why did you look out the window?
April: Huh? "Why"? Um, why what?
Phoenix: Why did you choose to look outside? Were you anticipating something?
April: Oh, well, um... gee!
Phoenix: (Seriously? She can't just dodge the question like that!)
April: I just sort of, y'know...
April: I had this feeling!
Phoenix: (A feeling...?)
Phoenix: (Should I press her a bit more on this?)
Phoenix: (Let's see how far I can push this line of questioning...)
Phoenix: Surely you must have had a clear reason to look out your window so late at night!
April: I... oooh!
Edgeworth: Mr. Wright! Stop badgering the witness!
Phoenix: B-badgering?
Edgeworth: You're relentlessly asking irrelevant questions!
Edgeworth: I believe this should not be permitted.
???: (That poor girl!)
Judge: Mr. Wright, you are being warned.
Phoenix: (Poor girl!? What about poor me!?)
Edgeworth: You looked out the window.\nWhat did you see next?
Phoenix: How did you recognize it was my client!?
April: Huh? Well, I... gee!
April: First, she had a girl's figure!
April: And second, she was... she was small!
April: Who else could it possibly be but her!
Phoenix: (She does have a point...)
Phoenix: Wait a second! Something's not right with your testimony!
April: W-what!?
Phoenix: Miss May, I'm going to call your statement into question...
Phoenix: Did you actually see the defendant at all!?
Judge: Mr. Wright! What's the meaning of this accusation?
April: Yes, please explain! Because I'm, like, totally lost!
Phoenix: Let me make this clear...
Phoenix: If you had truly seen my client, Maya Fey...
Phoenix: You would have recognized her clothes before anything else!
April: ...!
Phoenix: Her outfit is completely unique! Practically a signature look!
Phoenix: And even her hairstyle is anything but ordinary!
Phoenix: Yet your testimony mentions neither of these details!
Phoenix: This entire testimony is false!
April: But... but!
Judge: Even so, we can't confirm she was dressed the same that night...
Phoenix: She was, Your Honor!
Phoenix: I saw her myself!
Phoenix: And Detective Gumshoe can confirm it too!
Phoenix: Well, Miss May? What do you have to say to that?
April: Grr! You mean, mean lawyer!
April: I-I did see her!
April: I just... didn't think the tiny details were that important, sweetie.
Judge: Miss May.
Judge: The court reminds you to provide your complete and accurate testimony.
April: I'm so sorry, Your Honor. / I'll be a good girl now. / I promise. \*wink\*
Judge: Please deliver your testimony again.
Phoenix: (I was so close to breaking her...)
NAME: -- Witness's Account --
April: I really did see it all! I did!
April: The victimthe womandodged the first strike and ran to the right.
April: Then the girl in the strange clothes chased after her...
April: And she struck her with that weapon! I saw it all!
April: That... that clock! Um... the statue-like clock? "The Thinker," I think?
April: Well? Isn't my report surprisingly accurate? Tee hee!
Judge: I... understand.
Judge: I wish you had been this clear from the start.
Judge: Proceed with the cross-examination.
April: I did see everything! I did!
April: The victimthe womandodged the first strike and ran to the right.
April: Then the girl in the strange clothes ran after her...
April: And she struck her with that weapon! I saw it happen!
Phoenix: I present to the court... The Thinker.
Phoenix: Miss May.
April: Oh my, feeling bold, are you? Naughty Mr. Lawyer...
Phoenix: But there's no way to know it's a clock just by looking at it!
April: Urp!
Phoenix: Another person, in almost the same situation as you, also called this a "clock"...
Phoenix: Miss May. Can you explain how you knew this was a clock?
April: Oooh... urp!
Edgeworth: The witness saw the crime firsthand! That's all that matters!
Edgeworth: The defense is simply trying to muddy the waters with meaningless questions!
Judge: Yes... yes, of course. Mr. Wright, you will withdraw that question.
Phoenix: But questions are all I have, Your Honor!
Phoenix: And if you recall, I've solved cases using nothing but my questions!
Phoenix: (Okay, maybe just once...)
Judge: ...
Judge: Objection sustained. You may continue your questioning, Mr. Wright.
Phoenix: (Phew, that was close.)
Phoenix: (If he'd stopped me there, this trial would be over!)
April: Huh? What? So... what happens now?
Phoenix: What happens now is you answer my question! How did you know it was a clock?
April: Wh-what...! Th-that's...
April: ...Because... I heard it?
April: Yes! I heard it chime the time!
Phoenix: So, you've been to the Fey & Co. Law Offices!
April: N-n-no! Hey, I never said that! Why would I go there?!
Edgeworth: She could have heard the clock another way!
Phoenix: (I can't back down now!)
Phoenix: I'm not satisfied because...
Phoenix: Your Honor, members of the court...
Phoenix: It's impossible for that clock to have chimed!
Phoenix: That clock is missing its clockwork!
Judge: H-how could that be...?
Phoenix: See for yourself! Right now!
Judge: Oh!
Phoenix: Notice anything, Your Honor?
Judge: Just as the defense claims!
Judge: This clock is completely empty!
Judge: Mr. Wright!
Judge: Would you care to explain what this means to the court?
Phoenix: It's simple.
Phoenix: This witness...
Phoenix: is a liar!
Phoenix: Well, Miss May?
Edgeworth: Tsk, tsk.
Phoenix: ?
Edgeworth: Quite the spectacle you've created, Mr. Wright.
Phoenix: (He knew the clock was empty... he knew all along!)
Edgeworth: You've forgotten one crucial detail, however.
Edgeworth: The clock is empty, yes. But when was the clockwork removed?
Judge: !
Judge: An excellent point. It's possible it was emptied afterward.
Edgeworth: That is precisely what occurred, Your Honor!
Judge: Well, Mr. Wright?
Judge: Can you prove exactly when the clockwork was removed?
Edgeworth: Ho hoh! I doubt it...
Phoenix: Actually, I can.
Edgeworth: W-what!?
Phoenix: Wasn't it you who said "proof is everything"?
Phoenix: Well, I was listening.
Phoenix: And now I have the proof you crave!
Phoenix: The evidence that proves when the clockwork was removed is...
Phoenix: I present Maya's Cell Phone.
Phoenix: Take a listen to this recording.
April: Ooh hoo! A phone? How cute!
Phoenix: W-wait! This isn't mine!
Phoenix: This is the defendant's phone, with a recording of a conversation.
Phoenix: A conversation between her and the victim on the day of the murder!
Edgeworth: The defendant's cell phone!? I... was unaware of this!
Phoenix: Maybe Detective Gumshoe forgot to mention it?
Edgeworth: (Grumble) (That detective will regret this...)
Phoenix: (I'm almost starting to feel sorry for him...)
Phoenix: Let's hear the recording.
Cellular: *beep*
Phoenix: Your Honor,
Phoenix: This recording proves the clockwork was removed before this conversation took place.
Phoenix: Well before the witness ever checked into her hotel!
April: M-Muh... muh... muh!?
Phoenix: How did you know it was a clock, Miss May?
April: ...
April: W-well...!
April: I... I saw that clock before!
April: Um... at a store! I go to so many, I forgot which!
April: Oops! Silly me!\n*wink*
Judge: So the witness has seen the clock before. That seems reasonable.
Judge: Does the defense have any objections, Mr. Wright?
Phoenix: Yes, Your Honor. This contradicts existing evidence!
Judge: Please present this evidence.
Phoenix: It's simple.
Phoenix: This clock was never sold in any store!
April: W-whaaat!?
Phoenix: A friend of mine made it. Only two exist.
Phoenix: And the other one is in police custody!
April: I-I... Impossible! Everything's sold in stores!
April: Mmpf...
Phoenix: Oh? Excuses out of stock today?
April: Oooorrr...!
April: That dumb clock doesn't matter, okay!?
April: She did it! She should pay for it! Die! Die!
Judge: W-w-w!
Judge: This is a court of law, Miss May! Compose yourself!
April: Oh! Oh hoh ho! Silly me! *grunt*
April: Did I, um, like... lose it?
Phoenix: (S-scary...)
Judge: Miss May, allow me to ask.
Judge: How did you know the weapon was a clock?
Judge: Hmm... I see.
Judge: Mr. Wright, do you have any thoughts on this bizarre behavior?
Phoenix: (This is it... time to close the trap.)
Phoenix: Yes, Your Honor. I can explain everything.
Phoenix: Miss April May, you knew the weapon was a clock because...
Phoenix: (Same approach as Larry's case...)
Phoenix: You held that clock in your hands!
Judge: Mr. Wright! When was this!?
Phoenix: When she used it to strike the victim! When else?
Judge: Mr. Wright! What is the meaning of this accusation!?
Phoenix: April May, you killed Mia Fey!
Phoenix: And when you struck, the clock chimed!
Phoenix: That's how you knew it was a clock!
Edgeworth: ...
Edgeworth: You are truly something, Mr. Wright.
Phoenix: W-what's that supposed to mean!?
Edgeworth: You just proved "The Thinker" was empty.
Phoenix: Oh... (Urk! Of course it wouldn't chime!)
Edgeworth: And our witness has a solid alibi.
Edgeworth: Miss May?
Edgeworth: Would you be so kind as to explain?
April: It would be my pleasure!
April: Yes, Mr. Lawyer. Tee hee~
April: Didn't the murder happen at 9:00 PM?
April: That's when I ordered room service at my hotel!
Edgeworth: The bellboy confirms this account.
Edgeworth: Therefore, she was not at the crime scene. Her alibi is ironclad!
Judge: Mr. Wright! You've backed yourself into a corner!
Phoenix: S-sorry, Your Honor. (This isn't looking good...)
Phoenix: (But if she wasn't there...)
Phoenix: (Then how did she know "The Thinker" was a clock!?)
Phoenix: (...)
Phoenix: (Wait!)
Phoenix: Your Honor, I've figured it out!
Phoenix: There is one other way Miss April May could have known it was a clock!
Phoenix: One way only! And I have proof!
Judge: Proof, you say?
Judge: Very well. Present your evidence, Mr. Wright.
Judge: How did the witness know "The Thinker" was a clock?
Phoenix: I present... the Wiretap.
Phoenix: Please take a look at this.
April: Ah! Oooh! Th-that!? Eh heh...
Phoenix: I discovered this in Miss May's room.
Phoenix: Miss April May?
Phoenix: You were wiretapping the victim, Ms. Mia Fey's phone, weren't you?
Judge: I'm not entirely certain, but... Objection overruled.
Judge: I am disturbed by the fact that the witness possessed a wiretap.
Edgeworth: This is absurd! Are you claiming the witness was eavesdropping on the victim?
Phoenix: I most certainly am!
Edgeworth: Even if that were true, you must prove one thing!
Edgeworth: Did the victim ever mention that the weapon was a clock during any call?
Edgeworth: Can you prove that? I THINK NOT!
Phoenix: Oh yeah? I THINK I CAN! And it's simple!
Edgeworth: WH-WHAT!?
Phoenix: Here is my proof.
Phoenix: The proof that the victim mentioned the weapon was a clock is...
Phoenix: I present the defendant's cell phone.
Judge: Yes, we've already seen that.
Maya: [Mia! What's up? You haven't called in a while.]
Mia: [Well, actually, there's something I want you to hold on to for me.]
Maya: [Again? What's it this time?]
Mia: [It's... a clock.]
Mia: [It's made to look like that statue, "The Thinker." And it tells you the time!]
Phoenix: Miss April May!
Phoenix: You used a wiretap to listen to this conversation!
Phoenix: That's how you knew "The Thinker" was a clock!
Phoenix: Am I wrong!?
April: I... I...
Edgeworth: Your Honor, this is absurd!
Phoenix: Your Honor, look at the witness's expression! Does she look calm to you?
Phoenix: The defense demands an answer.
April: L-l-lrrrrgf!
Judge: Witness, answer the question. Did you wiretap the phone?
Judge: Miss May!
April: You... you LAWYER!
April: So I'm the bad girl now, huh? Is that it!? Is that it!?
Phoenix: (Now to deliver the final blow!)
Phoenix: Miss May, admit it. You did it, didn't you?
April: Are you insane!? Oh wait, you're a lawyer, so of course you are!
April: At the time of the murder...
April: I was in my hotel room, ordering room service!
April: How could I have killed her!?
April: If you don't believe me, just ask the bellboy!
Judge: Well, Mr. Wright? Do you wish to call this bellboy as a witness?
Phoenix: Um, well... (Come on, think of something!)
Phoenix: There's something suspicious here, and I'm going to uncover it!
April: I think you've sunk low enough already.
Edgeworth: I object to calling the bellboy!
Phoenix: W-why? What's your reason?
Edgeworth: Because I argue that the wiretapping has nothing to do with the murder!
Phoenix: ...!
Edgeworth: However...
Edgeworth: If you insist on calling this witness, I have a condition.
Phoenix: A condition...?
Edgeworth: If Miss April May's alibi is not disproven through the bellboy's testimony...
Edgeworth: then you must acknowledge Miss May's innocence.
Edgeworth: And by extension, you must also accept a verdict of "guilty" for Ms. Maya Fey!
Edgeworth: That is my condition.
Phoenix: (What...!?)
Phoenix: (If I can't find something suspicious in the bellboy's testimony, Maya is done for!)
Phoenix: (But this is my only chance!)
Phoenix: Very well. I accept your condition.
Edgeworth: Hmph.
Edgeworth: Fool... You've walked right into my trap!
Phoenix: (Uh oh...!)
Judge: Very well! The court will summon the bellboy as a witness.
Judge: The court now calls the hotel bellboy to the stand!
Edgeworth: I must say...
Edgeworth: He certainly has the look of a bellboy, doesn't he?
Bellboy: Yes, sir. Indeed I do, sir.
Bellboy: I received your summons right in the middle of my duties, sir. But I am honored to assist.
Judge: That tea set looks quite cumbersome, so let's proceed without delay.
Judge: The witness may begin his testimony.
Bellboy: Very good, sir!
Bellboy: I am the head bellboy of the prestigious Gatewater Hotel, a fine establishment with a proud history spanning four generations!
Bellboy: I recall receiving a call shortly after 8:00 PM from our guest, Miss May.
Bellboy: She requested an iced coffee to be delivered to her room at precisely 9:00 PM.
Bellboy: As requested, I delivered the coffee to her at exactly 9:00 PM.
Bellboy: And I handed it directly to Miss May herself.
Judge: I see. The defense may begin its cross-examination.
Phoenix: R-right! I'm ready. (I hope...)
Phoenix: (This is it...)
Phoenix: (If I can't prove Miss May's connection to the murder now...)
Phoenix: (Maya's fate is sealed!)
Bellboy: I am the head bellboy of the esteemed Gatewater Hotel, a proud establishment of four generations!
Bellboy: I remember receiving a call a little after 8:00 PM from our guest, Miss May.
Bellboy: She specifically requested an iced coffee to be delivered at exactly 9:00 PM.
Bellboy: And I personally delivered it to Miss May.
Phoenix: You are certain it was Miss April May herself?
Bellboy: Ab-SO-lutely, sir.
Phoenix: "Ab-SO-lutely"...? What does that mean exactly?
Bellboy: It means "so very absolutely," sir. A charming little habit of mine.
Phoenix: And how can you be so certain it was her?
Bellboy: Well, sir, when I brought the room service...
Bellboy: S-she... the guest, sir, was rather... affectionate, sir.
Phoenix: "Affectionate"? As in...?
Bellboy: She favored me with a, um, "embrasser," sir.
Phoenix: "Embrasser"? That's French for "kiss," isn't it?
Bellboy: Correct, sir. But not a French kiss, sir! Just a gentle peck on the cheek.
Phoenix: Wh-why would she have done that...?
Bellboy: Perhaps she was momentarily charmed by my polished demeanor, sir.
Bellboy: A moment I shall never forget, sir.
Phoenix: (This is... suspicious.)
Phoenix: (She might've been trying to make him remember her.)
Phoenix: (But why? What is she hiding?)
Phoenix: (I need to press him for something useful...)
Bellboy: I am the head bellboy of the Gatewater Hotel, a venerable institution spanning four generations!
Bellboy: I remember receiving a call just after 8:00 PM from Miss May.
Bellboy: She requested iced coffee to be delivered at 9:00 PM sharp.
Bellboy: I delivered it at the specified time, of course.
Phoenix: "Precisely" at 9:00 PM, you say?
Bellboy: Precisely, sir. To the very minute. 9:00 PM sharp.
Phoenix: And you're absolutely certain of that?
Bellboy: Oh, indeed. Miss May was quite insistent on the timing.
Bellboy: "Oh, bellboy? Tee hee! I'd like my iced coffee at exactly 9:00!" she said.
Bellboy: So I made certain to knock on her door right as the clock struck 9:00.
Phoenix: (Why would she be so precise about the time?)
Phoenix: ...
Phoenix: (This isn't getting me anywhere...)
Phoenix: (Is... is that it!?)
Edgeworth: Finally, you grasp it.
Edgeworth: This bellboy has no reason to deceive this court!
Edgeworth: Now...
Edgeworth: If you have any respect for this court's time, you will end this drawn-out cross-examination.
Judge: Hmm. I must admit it was rather prolonged.
Judge: The witness may be excused.
Phoenix: (I can't let this end like this...!)
Phoenix: W-wait! Please, wait!

evidences: ATTORNEY'S BADGE: No one would believe I was a defense attorney if I didn't carry this.

FLOOR PLANS: The murder scene, the Fey & Co. Law Offices. (The room is viewed from above, split into a lit center and darker corners. A door is at the top-right, and a large window is along the top wall, casting a cone-shaped beam of light inward. In the bottom-left, a plant has been knocked over near a fallen object, with debris scattered into the light. Two pieces of furniture (likely chairs) are overturned in the middle of the room. From the window's perspective, only the right half of the room is clearly visibleespecially the plant debris and doorway area. The far-left corner (where the struggle likely began) is obscured from view, suggesting a witness outside the window could misjudge the victim's movements.)
MAY TESTIMONY: "The victim dodged an attack then ran to the right, but she was caught and struck."
THE THINKER: The murder weapon. Looks like a statue, but it's actually a clock. Made by Larry Butz.
RECEIPT: A department store receipt with letters written in blood on the back.
WIRETAP: Found in Miss May's hotel room.
GLASS SHARDS: The broken remains of a glass light stand. Broken beyond all recognition.

MAYA'S CELL PHONE: Holds a conversation between the Chief and Maya. (September 5, 9:27 AM. Maya: Mia! What's up? You haven't called in a while. Mia: Well, actually there's something I want you to hold on to for me. Maya: Again? What is it this time? Mia: It's... a clock. It's made to look like that statue, 'The Thinker.' And it tells you the time! Ah... I should probably tell you, the clock isn't talking right now. Maya: Huh? It's not working? That's lame! Mia: I had to take the clockwork out, sorry. I put some papers inside it instead. Maya: Papers? Is that the evidence, then? Mia: I'll leave that one up to your imagination. See you tonight at nine.)
MIA'S AUTOPSY REPORT: Died from a blow by a blunt object. May have lived for a few minutes after being hit.

evidences: ATTORNEY'S BADGE: No one would believe I was a defense attorney if I didn't carry this.
Mia's Memo: A list of names in mias handwriting

FLOOR PLANS: The murder scene, the Fey & Co. Law Offices. (The room is viewed from above, split into a lit center and darker corners. A door is at the top-right, and a large window is along the top wall, casting a cone-shaped beam of light inward. In the bottom-left, a plant has been knocked over near a fallen object, with debris scattered into the light. Two pieces of furniture (likely chairs) are overturned in the middle of the room. From the window's perspective, only the right half of the room is clearly visibleespecially the plant debris and doorway area. The far-left corner (where the struggle likely began) is obscured from view, suggesting a witness outside the window could misjudge the victim's movements.)
MAY TESTIMONY: "The victim dodged an attack then ran to the right, but she was caught and struck."
THE THINKER: The murder weapon. Looks like a statue, but it's actually a clock. Made by Larry Butz.
RECEIPT: A department store receipt with letters written in blood on the back.
WIRETAP: Found in Miss May's hotel room.
GLASS SHARDS: The broken remains of a glass light stand. Broken beyond all recognition.

MAYA'S CELL PHONE: Holds a conversation between the Chief and Maya. (September 5, 9:27 AM. Maya: Mia! What's up? You haven't called in a while. Mia: Well, actually there's something I want you to hold on to for me. Maya: Again? What is it this time? Mia: It's... a clock. It's made to look like that statue, 'The Thinker.' And it tells you the time! Ah... I should probably tell you, the clock isn't talking right now. Maya: Huh? It's not working? That's lame! Mia: I had to take the clockwork out, sorry. I put some papers inside it instead. Maya: Papers? Is that the evidence, then? Mia: I'll leave that one up to your imagination. See you tonight at nine.)
MIA'S AUTOPSY REPORT: Died from a blow by a blunt object. May have lived for a few minutes after being hit.
